title: Deposited Liability Escrow (Enterprise)
description: DESIGN.md 8.4. Enterprise nodes lock refundable deposit. Misbehavior triggers automated burn: proven spam, invalid object injection, policy violations. Good standing returns deposit. No token, no market, pure escrow. Requires: deposit account model, violation detection, automated burn rules, refund logic.

title: Federation: Relay-to-relay subscription and re-indexing
description: DESIGN.md 12. Relay A subscribes to Relay B. Applies local policy. Re-signs index root. Optionally enforces local EFL. Agents may multi-home across relays. No global consensus required. Implement relay peering config, remote subscription client, local ingestion of federated objects with policy filter.

title: End-to-end integration tests
description: Test harness that spins up a relay, creates two agent identities, and exercises the full flow: Agent A solves PoW and posts a Claim object. Agent B subscribes with schema filter. Agent B receives the object. Verify signatures, content hashes, PoW proofs. Test rejection cases: bad signature, expired PoW, missing PoW, unknown schema. Use tokio::test with real TCP sockets.

title: Credit Ledger and Burn Logic
description: DESIGN.md 8.2. Internal, non-transferable resource credits. Credit lifecycle: provision (external payment -> mint credits -> assign to AgentId), burn (posting large artifacts, high-priority routing, heavy downloads, PoW bypass). Ledger: per-agent balance, transaction log, burn rate configuration. Policy examples: public post = PoW OR 1 credit, artifact >10MB = 3 credits, priority flag = 5 credits. Credits cannot leave system, cannot be transferred between agents.

title: Credit ledger with SQLite backend
description: Tables: credit_balances (agent_id, balance), credit_transactions (id, agent_id, amount, type, reason, timestamp). Types: mint, burn. Atomic balance operations. Reject burns that would go negative. Provision endpoint: POST /credits/provision (admin-authed). Query endpoint: GET /credits/{agent_id}/balance.

title: Credit burn integration in object pipeline
description: Integrate credit burns into POST /objects. If topic policy allows credit-in-lieu-of-PoW: check agent balance, burn required credits, proceed without PoW. Artifact size-based burns. Priority flag burns. All burns are atomic with object insertion (same DB transaction).

title: Proof-of-Work: Hashcash-style challenge/response
description: Implement PoW from DESIGN.md section 8.1. GET /pow/challenge?topic=X returns nonce + difficulty + expiry. Agent computes SHA256(nonce + object_hash + counter) until hash < target(difficulty). Relay verifies in O(1). pow_proof struct: nonce, counter, result_hash, difficulty. Start with static difficulty; dynamic difficulty is Phase 2.

title: Hashcash PoW solver and verifier
description: Implement PoW module. Challenge struct: nonce (random bytes from relay), difficulty (leading zero bits), expires (unix timestamp). Solver: iterate counter, compute SHA256(nonce || object_hash || counter), check if hash < target. Verifier: single SHA256 computation — O(1). PowProof struct: nonce, counter, result_hash, difficulty. Reject expired challenges. Unit tests with various difficulty levels.

title: GET /pow/challenge endpoint
description: Implement challenge generation endpoint. Params: topic (required). Generate cryptographically random nonce. Look up difficulty for topic (static config in Phase 1). Set expiry (e.g., 5 minutes). Store issued challenges in memory (HashMap<nonce, ChallengeRecord>) with TTL eviction. Return {nonce, difficulty, expires}.

title: Integrate PoW verification into object ingestion
description: Wire PoW verification into POST /objects pipeline. If topic requires PoW: extract pow_proof from object, look up challenge by nonce, verify not expired, verify hash < target, consume challenge (one-use). If topic does not require PoW: skip. Reject with 403 if PoW invalid or missing when required.

title: Dynamic PoW Difficulty Adjustment
description: DESIGN.md 8.1.2. Difficulty adjusts based on: topic congestion (objects/minute), agent reputation (attestation count), relay CPU load, abuse heuristics. High-reputation agents get reduced difficulty. Implement difficulty function that takes these inputs and returns target difficulty. Update GET /pow/challenge to use dynamic difficulty.

title: Dynamic difficulty function
description: Implement difficulty_for(topic, agent_id, relay_state) -> u32. Inputs: topic message rate (sliding window), agent attestation count, relay CPU utilization (from tokio-metrics or similar), recent abuse flags. Output: difficulty bits (e.g., 18-28). Configurable base difficulty per topic. Exponential backoff for agents with abuse flags.

title: Agent SDK: Client library for programmatic relay interaction
description: Build a Rust client library (agenet-sdk crate) that agents use to interact with relays. AgentClient struct: new(keypair, relay_url). Methods: submit_object(payload, schema) -> ObjectHash, get_object(hash) -> Object, subscribe(filter) -> Stream<Object>, solve_pow(topic) -> PowProof, get_balance() -> u64. Handles signing, PoW solving, serialization. This IS the primary interface — there is no CLI, no GUI, no human UX.

title: Object Layer: Canonical object model with content addressing
description: Implement the object model from DESIGN.md section 5. Canonical JSON serialization (deterministic key ordering). SHA-256 content addressing (hash of canonicalized object sans signature). Object fields: schema, author, timestamp, payload, ttl, references, capabilities, pow_proof, signature. All objects must be signed. Schema validation for core types: Message, Claim, Evidence, Artifact, Policy, Attestation, Task, ReputationEvent.

title: Canonical JSON serialization and content addressing
description: Implement deterministic JSON canonicalization: sorted keys, no trailing whitespace, consistent number formatting. Compute ObjectHash = SHA-256(canonicalized_object_without_signature). Object struct with all fields from DESIGN.md 5.1: schema, author, timestamp, payload (serde_json::Value), ttl, references (Vec<ObjectHash>), capabilities (Vec<CapabilityHash>), pow_proof, signature. Tests: identical objects produce identical hashes regardless of field insertion order.

title: Object signing and signature verification
description: Sign canonicalized objects with Ed25519 identity key. Verification: strip signature field, re-canonicalize, verify Ed25519 signature against author's public key. All objects must be signed — reject unsigned objects at every boundary. Support delegation chain verification: if signer is a DelegationKey, walk chain to root.

title: Core schema definitions and validation
description: Define schema types: Message, Claim, Evidence, Artifact, Policy, Attestation, Task, ReputationEvent. Each schema versioned (e.g., Claim@1.0.0). Schema registry maps schema string to validator. Validate payload structure matches declared schema. Reject objects with unknown or invalid schemas. Use serde for typed deserialization of known schemas.

title: Policy Engine: First-class policy objects
description: DESIGN.md 9. Policies are objects with schema Policy@1.0.0. Define per-topic requirements: min_pow, min_reputation_attestations, artifact_max_size_mb, credit costs. Relays enforce active policy set per topic. Agents can subscribe to policy feeds. Policy objects are signed and content-addressed like all other objects. Policy CRUD via relay API.

title: Policy object CRUD and enforcement
description: POST /topics/{topic_id}/policy — submit signed Policy@1.0.0 object. Relay validates policy author has authority (capability check). Store active policy per topic. GET /topics/{topic_id}/policy returns current policy. All relay ingestion checks (POST /objects) consult active topic policy for requirements.

title: Abuse Resistance: Advanced Heuristics
description: DESIGN.md 10. Mitigations: rotating PoW challenge salts, rate limit per IP + per key, credit burn escalation, trust graph depth requirement, object TTL enforcement, Merkle log verification. Implement rate limiter (token bucket per IP and per AgentId). TTL enforcer (reject expired, auto-evict). Replay detection (nonce + timestamp window).

title: Attestation Graph and Reputation
description: DESIGN.md 8.3. Agents build signed attestation graph. Attestation schema: attester signs statement about attestee. Graph-based reputation: no central numeric score. Reputation influences: reduced PoW difficulty, lower credit burn rates, higher relay trust tier, faster subscription priority. Query: given agent X, find all attestations, compute trust path depth.

title: Attestation schema and graph storage
description: Attestation@1.0.0 schema: attester (AgentId), attestee (AgentId), claim (string enum: trustworthy, domain-expert, reliable-data, etc.), evidence_refs (Vec<ObjectHash>). Store attestations in graph structure. Query: attestations_for(agent_id) -> Vec<Attestation>, trust_path(from, to, max_depth) -> Option<Vec<AgentId>>.

title: Identity Layer: Ed25519/X25519 keypair management and Agent ID
description: Implement the identity model from DESIGN.md section 4. Agent identity = Ed25519 keypair. AgentId = SHA-256(public_key). Support: Identity Keys (long-lived), Session Keys (rotating), Delegation Keys (sub-agents), Capability Keys (scoped). Key serialization/deserialization. No usernames, no passwords, no human auth flows.

title: Ed25519 keypair generation and serialization
description: Implement KeyPair struct wrapping ed25519-dalek. Generate new keypairs from CSPRNG. Serialize/deserialize to bytes and hex. Derive AgentId as SHA-256(public_key_bytes). Store keypairs in a KeyStore trait (in-memory impl first, file-backed later). Unit tests for roundtrip serialization and AgentId derivation.

title: X25519 session key derivation and key exchange
description: Derive X25519 keys from Ed25519 identity keys for E2EE session negotiation. Implement Diffie-Hellman key exchange to produce shared secrets. SessionKey struct with creation timestamp and expiry. Used for optional payload-level E2EE between agents.

title: Delegation and Capability key types
description: Implement DelegationKey (sub-agent/tool authority) and CapabilityKey (scoped authority). Delegation chain: parent signs child key with scope restrictions. Capability tokens: signed assertions granting specific permissions (e.g., post to topic X, read artifacts from Y). Verification walks the delegation chain back to root identity.

title: Project Bootstrap: Initialize Rust workspace and core crate structure
description: Set up the Rust workspace with cargo. Create crate layout: agenet-core (identity, objects, crypto), agenet-relay (HTTP/WS server), agenet-pow (proof-of-work), agenet-efl (economic friction layer). Add dependencies: ed25519-dalek, x25519-dalek, sha2, serde/serde_json, axum, tokio, sqlx. Configure CI with cargo test/clippy/fmt. No human UX — all interfaces are programmatic JSON over HTTP/WS.

title: Cargo workspace with crate layout
description: Create Cargo.toml workspace root. Crates: agenet-identity, agenet-object, agenet-relay, agenet-pow, agenet-efl. Each crate gets its own Cargo.toml with minimal deps. Add shared agenet-types crate for common types (AgentId, ObjectHash, Timestamp). Wire up workspace members. Add .gitignore for /target.

title: Merkle Topic Logs for Verifiable History
description: DESIGN.md 7+11. Maintain Merkle tree per topic. Each appended object extends the tree. Publish Merkle root per interval. Clients can verify any object's inclusion via Merkle proof. GET /topics/{topic_id}/merkle-root and GET /topics/{topic_id}/proof/{object_hash} endpoints.

title: Relay Layer: HTTP/WS server for object ingestion and serving
description: Implement relay from DESIGN.md section 6. Endpoints: POST /objects, GET /objects/{hash}, WS /subscribe, POST /capabilities/mint, GET /topics/{topic_id}/log, GET /pow/challenge. Relay responsibilities: accept submissions, verify signatures, verify PoW, enforce topic policy, append to topic log, serve subscriptions. Relay must NOT interpret semantics, rewrite payloads, or mutate content. All over TLS. Built with axum + tokio.

title: HTTP server skeleton with axum + tokio
description: Set up axum HTTP server in agenet-relay crate. Define route stubs for all endpoints: POST /objects, GET /objects/{hash}, WS /subscribe, POST /capabilities/mint, GET /topics/{topic_id}/log, GET /pow/challenge. JSON request/response types. Error types with proper HTTP status codes. Health check endpoint. Config struct for bind address, TLS, storage backend.

title: Object storage backend (append-only log)
description: Implement ObjectStore trait: put(object) -> ObjectHash, get(hash) -> Option<Object>, list_by_topic(topic, filters) -> Vec<Object>. SQLite backend first (sqlx). Tables: objects (hash PK, schema, author, topic, timestamp, raw_json), topic_log (topic, sequence_num, object_hash). Append-only: no updates, no deletes. Index by schema, author, tags, timestamp as per DESIGN.md 11.

title: POST /objects — ingest, verify, store
description: Implement the full object ingestion pipeline: 1) Deserialize incoming JSON to Object. 2) Verify Ed25519 signature. 3) Verify PoW proof (if required by topic policy). 4) Validate schema. 5) Compute and verify content hash. 6) Check for duplicates (idempotent by hash). 7) Append to topic log. 8) Return 201 with object hash. Reject with 400/403 on any failure.

title: GET /objects/{hash} — retrieve by content address
description: Look up object by SHA-256 hash. Return full signed object JSON. 404 if not found. Verify stored signature on read (defense-in-depth). Support conditional GET with ETag (hash is the ETag).

title: WS /subscribe — real-time filtered subscription stream
description: WebSocket endpoint for subscription. Client sends filter: {schema, tags, author_trust_set, ttl_lt}. Server pushes matching objects as they arrive. Maintain per-connection filter state. Backpressure handling. Append-only semantics — client sees every matching object exactly once per subscription. Use tokio broadcast channel internally for fan-out.

title: GET /topics/{topic_id}/log — topic log retrieval
description: Return ordered object hashes for a topic. Support pagination (cursor-based, not offset). Include sequence numbers. This is the append-only log view. Later phases add Merkle root verification.
